item.title: Open Government
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
“Democracy” initially stands for: the power to the people. Do you feel like you are in control? If you answered no, learn what Open Government is and why we should adopt it !

Introduction

Most of the modern democracies are in fact some form of representative democracies. Meaning that the people elects representatives that will then rule the country by creating, applying and interpreting laws. This leads to situation where the people actually express its will only by electing representatives, so approximately once per year.

Now, why wouldn’t we form some direct democracies ? The main argument, few centuries ago, was that it was not possible to manage a whole population voting on each issue. And this was fine then. But is it now ?

Opinion and Argumentation

In my opinion, of course, it is not: today democracies are obsolete. We have the necessary means to create more direct democracies, which I consider better.

Why are more direct democracies better?

I consider direct democracies to be better for many reasons and here are a few:

  • You might agree on most subject with the person you elect to represent you but what about the other subjects ? Wouldn’t it be easier (except for organizational reasons) to represent yourself… well yourself ?
  • The person you elected to represent you is generally elected for a time span (often a few years). What if that person changes with time ? You cannot tell what he/she will be in 2 or three years.
  • Most of the politicians come from higher social classes. This is problematic, because the population might not be represented equitably.
  • etc.

Why more direct democracies instead of direct democracies?

In think that specialization, to some extend, is great idea and beneficent tool. Following that reasoning, I would say that there are complicated subjects and decisions about those should be delegated to groups of experts specialized in that subject. Also, it would be impossible to have the people vote on every issues a government faces. In my view, neither extreme is good and we are at the representative extreme.

What Now ?

OK, so more direct democracies are probably better. What do we do now?

Wait for it… Open Government

Definition

Note: the definition below might not correspond to the generally accepted definition, or put emphasis on different parts.

Open Government: An Open Source movement that aims to make government data open to the public and to promote civic participation.

What it Could Be

Imagine that your government creates an app or website which allows you to vote, to obtain official dataset easily, to complete administrative procedures and to report problems (like pothole, broken stuffs, etc.). Individuals’ life would be easier, contacts with the government would make society more efficient, resources would be better used and transparency would make it harder for corruption to exist. This is what Open Government could look like.

You can even think it one step further. For example, if there existed a platform where you could download governmental dataset, then you could imagine having citizen or universities doing data mining on it to find ways to optimize how resources are used.

A Little Example

A few months back, I traveled to Europe. During my trip, I visited a few countries, one of which is quite relevant to the thematic at hand: Switzerland.

This little country has a very peculiar system and the Swiss people votes on average four times a year on elections but also on policies and so-called initiatives. My point being: There exists some countries where a more direct democracy is used and it works. In fact it works greatly for Switzerland:

Switzerland has a stable, prosperous and high-tech economy and enjoys great wealth, being ranked as the wealthiest country in the world per capita in multiple rankings. Wikipedia, 04-09-2018

item.title: Why Changing Matters?
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
We live in a very peculiar time, one of technologies, of increasing speed, of ever evolving theories and concepts. To survive in such hostile environment, one has to adapt… fast! This often imply learning new things to stay up to date, forging new habits, changing one’s way of thinking, embracing new cultures, etc.

A Philosophy of Change

Why Change Matters

The reasons cited above make me believe that change is an important skill to master.

But change can bring oneself more than just a way to adapt, it can be an occasion to discover new cultures, new persons, maybe new friends. Trying to change can lead the way to creating unforgettable memories, which in the end are all the things a human being truly possesses. It can make you to be more knowledgeable, make you wiser, make you discover new points of view, etc.

And for all those reasons, I like changing.

How to Change?

Adapt Yourself To Adaptation

Adaptation is one of the most fundamental way of surviving on the long term. It used to be a lengthy process that could take many years.

But nowadays adaptation has to happen fast. For example, when you start a new job, you may have to learn new skills in a matter of weeks. If you move out to another country, you may have to insert yourself into a new culture. Or even imagine you finally proposed to your girlfriend to move in, you will then have to adapt to a new every day life if you don’t want your relationship to go south (OK, this last example might be a bit exaggerated but you get the idea). You never know what life has planned for you.

So how can one be ready to adapt to change?

Well, I believe that changing is a skill that can be learn. Hence, the more you change, the easier you’ll find it to change, it is a circle. So to ready yourself, you have to change regularly.

How can one change regularly will you ask me… Well, in my opinion, it implies renouncing to some of your routines or habits. Do you have a café where you always like to go to chat with your friends? Do you have a preferred spot in the library where you always go to work or read? Do you always eat the same things at the cafeteria?

If this is the case, try changing those little things: try another meal, seat somewhere else (or even try another library), choose another café, etc. Doing this will put you outside of your comfort zone, and I won’t lie: at first, it is not easy! Habits are comfortable, they work as landmark in our everyday life and abandoning them implies to have the courage of embracing the unknown. To diminish the initial fear of change, try very small changes and increase progressively the changes’ importance.

In the end you will feel comfortable even if you find yourself in a totally unknown place with totally unknown persons doing totally unknown things because you will be confident that you can adapt to the situation.

Always Learn

Another way to change is to learn new things, when possible on very differentiated subjects. One can do this, for example, by reading books and taking notes on them. And I will emphasize here on the importance of learning things on differentiated subjects. This is one of the most efficient ways I have ever found to widen or even change my points of view.

Changes to Undertake?

Easy ones

  • Try new meals
  • Seat somewhere else than your usual spot

Intermediate Level

  • Learn something new by reading a book
  • Test a new sport (Try something crazy like Parkour)

For the Hardcore Ones

  • Try learning to write with the wrong hand
  • Try learning a new language (Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, etc).

item.title: The Open (Source), a Revolution
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
The open source movement is an alternative way of working and cooperating that could very well change our society. It is based on cooperation instead of exchanges and is already a standard in the digital world. But many applications of it are possible especially in the real world.

The Open (Source), a Revolution

Back to the Origins: The Open Source Movement

A Quick Definition of Open Source

An open source software must provide the four following liberties:

  1. The liberty to use the software
  2. The liberty to view the source code (useful if you want to learn how to code for example)
  3. The liberty to modify the code (so that you can take a program and modifz it in order to make it match your exact needs)
  4. The liberty to distribute your modified version of the code

The Main Characteristic of Open Source

The whole idea behind open source software is that a program should rely on a community of users and programmers. This community can then propose changes, implement them and make them available to all! By doing that you give the control back to the persons that use the software. That way, you are certain that the software corresponds to the needs of the persons using it. And if the community is big enough it also ensure great quality of code, a lot of support provided by more experienced user to least experienced ones, rapid improvements and adaptation to newer needs, etc.

In a somewhat broader sense, one could consider an open source software as simply a cooperation between human beings. By improving the program, you will not gain money but you will be cooperating with humanity.

Examples of Open Source Software

Open source software are everywhere. Here are a few examples:

  • The linux operating system
  • The android operating system
  • Firefox
  • LibreOffice
  • Gimp (used for photo editing)
  • Blender (to create animated movies)
  • etc.

In fact, at least 70% of the Internet is run by open source software (the vast majority of the computers powering Internet run Linux as operating system, most of the web server like Apache are open source, most of the protocols on the internet are open source, etc.). Almost all programming languages are open source too.

Amongst non-open source software, one can find: The Apple ecosystem (iOs, Pages, Keynote, etc.), the Microsoft ecosystem (Windows, Microsoft Office, etc), the Adobe ecosystem (Photoshop, InDesign, etc.).

Fine, But Why Should I Care?

Open source software is probably of little concern for you, but the ideas it conveys certainly are not!

From the open source originated a lot of other open movements like:

  • Open Hardware (Arduino and RaspberryPi for example)
  • Open Beer (open beer receipes)
  • Open Data (data available to all online to easily make statistics or researches)
  • Open Science
  • Open Government

A Revolution

I believe that all those movements will transform our society in a very profound manner. They highlight the fact that cooperation is a possible alternative to our system based on exchanges (can you imagine a world without money? Well, the people that created the open source apparently could!). And with the rise of new technologies like the Internet, open alternative will be easier and easier to put in place.

For example, Open Government is a way of implying the people living in a society in their governance. The idea is to facilitate the communication between the government and the people: more transparency from the government to the society, more inputs from the people to the government, etc. This could simplify the democratic process and even increase it.

All in all I strongly hope that open source will impose itself and maybe even change our society!

item.title: The Rules of Inference
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
Simple binary operators aren’t a structure powerful enough to define rules of reasoning. This is where rules of inference come into play. They are forms of reasoning that we can prove to be correct. Let’s discover a few of them.

This article is the fourth in a series of four:

  1. Boolean Logic
  2. “Complex” Boolean Operators
  3. Boolean Algebra
  4. Rules of Inference

Rules of Inference

The general idea is the following: some propositions \( P_1 \), …, \( P_n \) are assumed to be true and one shows that accepting those propositions logically (in the sense of boolean logic) leads to saying that a conclusion proposition \( P_c \) must also be true.

\( P_1 \) to \( P_n \) are called the premises. \( P_c \) is called the conclusion.

There are quite many rules of inferences, here I will only cite the most useful ones. Note that the rules of inferences do not concern themselves with the truth of the premises. They are only used to deduce conclusions when we assume the premises to be true.

Modus Ponens

This form of argumentation is based on two premises:

  • \( P\rightarrow Q \) (The proposition “if \( P \) is true, then \( Q \) is true” is true)
  • \( P \) ( \( P \) is true)

From this, we can conclude that \( Q \) is true.

Example:

  • If you are rich, then you are beautiful
  • You are rich

It follows logically that you are beautiful!

It is possible to prove these rules using the boolean algebra defined in a previous article. The proof for this rule of inference is given thereafter. The proofs for the others rules of inference will not be given. One can find them online or derive them using boolean algebra.

item.title: "Complex" Boolean Operators
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
The boolean operators negation, AND and OR suffice to represent all expressions. However, it might some time be easier to define a few more operators for the sake of simplicity. In this article, I will cover the if then and equivalence operators.

This article is the second article in a series of four:

  1. Boolean Logic
  2. “Complex” Boolean Operators
  3. Boolean Algebra
  4. Rules of Inference

Two More Binary Operators

Implies (if … then …)

Let’s define the implication operator \( \rightarrow \). It is a binary operator with the following truthtable:

\( A \) \( B \) \( C = A \rightarrow B \)
T T T
T F F
F T T
F F T

We remark that \( C \) is false only when \( A \) is true and \( B \) is false.

I pretend that this operator is equivalent to saying “if A, then B”.

Let us define three propositions:

\( A \) = “I am elected maire”

\( B \) = “I increase taxes”

\( C \) = \( A \rightarrow B \)

I will now try to prove that this is the same as the sentence “If I am elected maire, then I will increase the taxes”.

Imagine a politician P, saying “If I am elected maire, then I will increase the taxes”. If P is elected and he/she raises the taxes then he did not lie and C is true. If P is elected but he/she does not increase the taxes, then he/she lied and the proposition was in fact false. If P is not elected, then he/she said the truth when saying that if he/she got elected, he/she would raise the taxes in the sense that the person did not lie. We see the exact same values in the truthtable of the implication operator.

Equivalence

Let us finally define the binary operator equivalence represented with the symbol \( \leftrightarrow \) with the following truthtable:

\( A \) \( B \) \( A \leftrightarrow B \)
T T T
T F F
F T F
F F T

I pretend that the equivalence operator applied to two propositions is equivalent to saying that two propositions are equivalent. This comes from the fact that for two propositions to be equivalent, they need, for any given input, to be either both true or both false, but they cannot have different values. One can remark that this is exactly what the truthtable says.

Extended Precedence Rules

We already saw the rules of precedence for the negation, AND and OR operators. We now complete those rules with the two newly defined operators.

  1. Negation
  2. AND
  3. OR
  4. Implication
  5. Equivalence

More binary operators

There exists many more binary operators (XOR, XAND, etc) but the ones above are generally enough.

Conclusion

With those tools in hand, we are ready to discover some simple rules of algebra that govern the world of logic and that we will later use to prove what a correct reasoning is. Simple rules of algebra will be the topic of the next article: Boolean Algebra .

item.title: An Introduction to Boolean Logic
item.author: Jonathan Bennett
item.description:
A strong and correct reasoning must, at the very least, be rooted in a rock solid logic. This article tries to explain the basics of the boolean logic, one of the most commonly used logic in mathematics.

It is the first article in a series of four:

  1. Boolean Logic
  2. “Complex” Boolean Operators
  3. Boolean Algebra
  4. Rules of Inference

The final goal of this series is to derive the so-called rules of inference that are rules to apply for correct reasoning.

Some Definitions

Proposition

Proposition
Let’s define a proposition \( P \) as a sentence that can either be true or false, and nothing else (law of excluded middle).

Example: \( P \) = “It is snowing”

Remark: Some might argue that, in real life, a perfect binarity most often doesn’t exist. It is more likely that a property can take a value in a gradient of possible values. I totally agree with this point of view. But I think it is still possible to define propositions that are either true or false but nothing else, by considering ranges of values.

For example, assume I define \( P \) as “X has brown hair”. X might have dark brow hair, or aubrun hair… Is \( P \) true or false then? One possible solution is to better define the proposition \( P \) as “X has hair that are brown or darker”.

Compound Proposition

Compound Proposition
I now define a compound proposition as a proposition that is defined by relationships between other propositions. I will call the other propositions input propositions. The relationships are defined using operators. We will see a few of them below.
Truthtable
Let’s also define the truthtable of a compound proposition as a table showing all the possible values that the input propositions can take and the value that the compound proposition take given the values of the input propositions. For conciseness, true will be written T and false will be written F inside truthtables.

To create a compound proposition, one must link or combine one or more propositions together. To combine propositions one uses so-called operators, they simply represent the kind of relationship there is between two propositions.

I will now define a few ways to combine propositions using unary and binary operators (operators that are applied on a single proposition or two propositions respectively).

Operators

Negation

Let’s define a unary operation on a proposition called the negation of a proposition in the following way, the negation of a proposition that is true will yield false, the negation of a proposition that is false will yield true. The negation of a proposition \( P \) is represented in the following way: \( \neg P \). A second way to represent the negation of \( P \) is \( \bar P \). I will use one or the other depending on which is more comfortable to read in a given context.

Here is the truthtable of the negation operation:

\( P \) \( \bar{P} \)
T F
F T

I will now try to show that the negation operation corresponds to the negation as we understand it in the english language.

Let me define \( P \) as “It is snowing”. This can either be true or false. Let me also remark that \( P \) yields true when it is snowing and false otherwise.

I pretend that the negation of a proposition is equivalent to the negation of the sentence that the proposition represent. I am not sure if it is even possible to make a rigorous proof of this. I can only hope that the following example convinces you, that you find it obvious enough or that someone propose us a proper proof of it. This remark is valid for all following operators where I try to show the correspondences to the human language.

We now consider \( \bar{P} \). By the definition of the negation operator, \( \bar{P} \) will yield false when it snows and true when it is not snowing. This is equivalent to the proposition “It is not snowing” because it yield true when it is not snowing and false when it is snowing.

Axiom: For a proposition defined as a sentence, the negation operation on the proposition is the same as the negation as we understand it in the English language of the sentence.

AND

Let me represent the AND operator with the following symbol: \( \wedge \). The AND-composition of two propositions \( A \) and \( B \) is then represented the following way: \( A \wedge B \)

Furthermore, I define the truthtable of the AND-operator as follow:

\( A \) \( B \) \( A\wedge B \)
T T T
T F F
F T F
F F F

In other words, \( A \wedge B \) is true if and only if \( A \) is true and \( B \) is true simultaneously.

I pretend that the AND operator on two propositions \( A \) and \( B \) is equivalent to saying “A and B” as we understand it in the English language.

Let’s consider the following propositions:

\( A \) = “I have brown eyes”

\( B \) = “I possess a car”

\( C \) = \( A \wedge B \)

We see that C, by the definition of the AND operator is only true if both \( A \) and \( B \) are true simultaneously. We can also remark that the same reasoning applies in English: For us not to be liars when we say “I have brown eyes and I possess a car”, then we must both have brown eyes and possess a car.

Axiom: The AND operator applied on two propositions \( A \), \( B \) is equivalent to saying “\( A \) and \( B \)” as we understand it in English.

OR

Let me define the OR operator as being false only if both \( A \) and \( B \) are false simultaneously. I also define the following notation to represent it: \( A \vee B \).

Here is the truthtable of the OR operator:

\( A \) \( B \) \( A \vee B \)
T T T
T F T
F T T
F F F

Remark: the OR operator does not correspond to the English “or”. Let’s remark that when someone says “I can have an apple or a banana”, what is meant is that the person can have either an apple or a banana, but not both. The OR operator would mean that you can have one or both.

We pretend that the OR operator is equivalent to saying “A or B or both”.

Precedence Rules

For complex expressions involving many operators, we need to know in which order the operators are to be applied.

We arbitrarily define the following order:

  1. Negation
  2. AND
  3. OR

We will use parenthesis to modify the order in which to apply the operators, in the following way: the operators inside a parenthesis should be applied before the operators outside of the parenthesis.

Conclusion

These only three operators are enough for all the boolean logic. They allow us to represent every possible operation on any number of input variables. However, for the sake of brevity and simplicity, it is often preferable to define some more operators; two, in fact, that also have meaning in the spoken language. This will be the topic of the next article: Complex Boolean Operators
